statement:
The conjugacy classes of a group form a partition of its elements. In a
finite group, this means that the order of the group is the sum of the
number of elements of the distinct conjugacy classes. For an element $g$
of group $G$, we denote the centralizer in $G$ of $g$ by $C_G(g)$. The
number of elements in the conjugacy class of $g$ is $[G:C_G(g)]$, the
index of $C_G(g)$ in $G$. For an element $g$ of the center $Z(G)$ of
$G$, the conjugacy class of $g$ consists of the singleton $\{g\}$.
Putting this together gives us the *class equation*
$$|G| = |Z(G)| + \sum_{i=1}^m [G:C_G(x_i)]$$ where the $x_i$ are
elements of the distinct conjugacy classes contained in
$G\setminus Z(G)$.
